intro: Rhysolepis pilosa, commonly known as the hairy mountain-mahoe, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its small, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant has opposite, ovate leaves that are covered in fine, soft hairs, giving it a distinctive textured appearance. It typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in woodland areas. Rhysolepis pilosa is often used in gardens for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in partial shade.
